article_title: New paramedicine programs could lose current funding source
article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com.

article_metadata.description: Fort Bend, Montgomery counties aim to cut amount of 911 calls by visiting regular emergency patients at home  [...] she has not dialed the emergency number yet this year.  The new program, launched this year, is designed to address the underlying causes of why some people frequently call 911 and to help those individuals develop a stable treatment routine to keep them out of emergency rooms, where costs often fall to taxpayers.  Without a federal renewal, the state could lose $4 billion in annual funding for the program, which was intended as a transition toward expanding Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act.  [...] Republicans who control state government have opposed such an expansion to cover some 1 million uninsured Texans, mostly with federal funds, and now U.S. officials have signaled they might not allow the waiver funding to pay for people who would be covered under such an expanded Medicaid program.  The feud has left local governments wondering how to continue community paramedicine and other programs that rely on the waiver and associated funding.  The paramedic helped her find regular physicians and start regular kidney dialysis, and taught her the best timing for taking her medications.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jayme Fraser

Without a federal renewal, the state could lose $4 billion in annual funding for the program, which was intended as a transition toward expanding Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act. The feud has left local governments wondering how to continue community paramedicine and other programs that rely on the waiver and associated funding.
